ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Reading long papers quickly for key points, facilitating discussion, more about practical applications for historical linguistics

How to read contemporary articles in the field. Theories of language change and evolution. How to test for relatedness. How to conduct a semi-original research project and write up a report on it. What factors influence language ideologies. How does language affect people and groups. How language has been seen and used as a tool in history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Sometimes disorganized and assignments were often unclear, but discussions were worth the confusion since the class was small and the prof is really knowledgeable about a broad range of linguistics things

Strengths: interesting content, great discussion format, wonderful and brilliant teacher, small class size, EXTREMELY generous deadlines and workload, provided you actually do put in the effort. 

Weaknesses: class was a bit disorganized, and at times I dont think I really received any input on how I was doing in the course or what I could/should improve on, especially leading up to the final.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if youre wondering what is the use of figuring out the history of languages? this is the class for you.

Yeah! If you liked Historical 1, this is like the real linguistics version of that. There wont be right answers, only debates where you have to justify your responses. You will learn a great deal about things you had never really considered before, and youll get the chance to do it from a professor who is brilliant and caring.
